The post How to Cancel Republic Services (Read This First) appeared first on P3 Cost Analysts.


Waste management companies are notorious for these unfair contracts, and Republic Services is no exception. There are many people out there trying to cancel Republic Services, only to be met with a complicated process or no response from their representatives. If this is you, keep reading to get a better understanding of the Republic Services cancellation process and figure out how to get the help you need.


Republic Services is a prominent waste management company that provides a comprehensive range of waste collection and disposal services. Claiming a commitment to sustainability and environmental stewardship, Republic Services focuses on managing waste responsibly while offering efficient and reliable solutions. The company serves millions of residential, commercial, industrial, and municipal customers across the United States.


Republic Services offers various waste management services tailored to meet diverse needs. Their residential services encompass curbside waste collection, recycling programs, and yard waste removal. For businesses, Republic Services provides customized waste and recycling solutions, including commercial dumpster rentals, compactor services, and comprehensive waste management plans.


Many people find themselves or their business in an undesirable contract with Republic Services. Often, these contracts have favorable terms for Republic Services, while the other party gets the short end of the stick.


If you’re considering entering into an agreement with Republic Services, you should consider the following things:


Additional fees popping up on your invoice are not unique to Republic Services. The entire waste management industry is known for having billing errors and overcharges on their invoices. Republic Services outlines the fees that may appear on their invoices in the contract for invoice-to-invoice agreements. These include:


Not only should you expect your contract to include clauses for many different types of fees, but Republic Services is also known to include rate increases for services that may or may not be lawful. The waste management company has been on the receiving end of various lawsuits due to unlawful rate increases and fuel recovery fees, according to the website Republic Services Exposed. Knowing that Republic has already had issues with unlawful rate increases may cause business owners to seek Republic Services’ contract termination methods.


The same website also reports that Republic Services has been forced to refund millions of dollars to their customers due to unauthorized fees and overcharges. Customers are responsible for finding these errors and invoices and submitting a claim for a refund. Most business owners don’t have time to dedicate to this process and therefore end up overspending on trash collection. Companies like P3 Cost Analysts can help businesses immensely by handling invoice audits for them or helping them cancel Republic Services.


In addition to employing questionable contract tactics, Republic Services lacks transparency and standard pricing. Some sales representatives prioritize commissions by encouraging customers to pay more for services, and business owners can’t trust that their representatives have their best interests at heart.


If you go to the customer support portion of their website, the Republic Services Cancellation Policy looks pretty straightforward. Just give them a call and speak to your representative. In reality, many customers have a very hard time getting a hold of anyone to speak to at all.


To guarantee the best success rate, we recommend working with a professional waste management auditor like P3 Cost Analysts, as there are numerous roadblocks not covered here Republic could put in your way. If you would like to go it alone, the following steps can serve as a guide for you.


You should have read the fine print of your contract, like the terms and conditions, before signing. But if it’s been a while, or you didn’t pay close enough attention, you should go back to your contract before reaching out to your representative. Find out the specific cancellation requirements as outlined in your contract so you enter the conversation with all the necessary information and don’t experience any surprises.


The next step is to call Republic Services. According to their website, you can find a phone number for your representative on the front of your invoice. Another option is to call their customer support line. Before calling, gather all the necessary account information to make the process smoother. Some customers may also have the option to cancel through the customer portal.


It’s important to note that the Republic Services Cancellation Policy states that advance notice is required to cancel their services. Oftentimes it will not go into effect until 30 days after they receive cancellation.


If you’re able to get a hold of your Republic Services representative or a customer support agent, clearly state that your intention is to cancel their services. Waste management companies often make it difficult for their customers to get out of the contract, so they may try to convince you to stay with them. It would be a good idea to document the time, date, and name of the representative you’re speaking with in case you run into problems down the line. It’s highly likely they will reference the contract or refer to the fact you are in an auto-renewal period at this time.


If the representative you speak with gives you any further instructions on how to finish the Republic Services contract termination process, make sure you complete each step. This may include instructions on what to do with any equipment of theirs or official forms you need to fill out.


There have been reports of people requesting cancellation but continuing to be charged by Republic Services. Request a confirmation of the cancellation in writing just in case they continue to charge you after your requested cancellation date. Be sure to check for future invoices and keep an eye out for any refunds you’re expecting.


If you’re struggling with these steps on your own, save yourself the frustration. Companies like P3 Cost Analysts have decades of experience going up against giant waste-hauling companies like Republic Services. We can help you figure out how to cancel Republic Services, as well as help you find a better waste-hauling company and monitor future invoices for errors and overcharges from your next provider.


With so many customers having issues with Republic Services and other heavy hitters such as Waste Management, some have started to look for smaller, more local waste-hauling companies that may provide a better customer experience. These organizations are also likely to be more flexible during contract negotiations.


In many cases, Republic may be your best option. But in some cases you have choices. If you want Republic Services to stop service to your home or business, you’ll need to find another waste hauler to replace them.


The first step is to cancel Republic Services; then you can begin shopping around for new providers. However, it’s important not to get locked into another predatory contract. P3 Cost Analysts can step in here to help you negotiate an agreement that serves you.


There is no shortage of disappointed customers working with Republic Services, just like most of the other major waste-hauling providers. Unfortunately, these contracts are often written in favor of the supplier, leaving businesses and residences stuck with no way out.


Republic Services makes it appear that the Republic Services Stop Service Process is straightforward and simple. Just follow the steps – look at your contract, contact your representative, and request a cancellation. Unfortunately, many people don’t have such a simple experience.


If you’re looking for help at any stage of the waste management contract process, contact P3 Cost Analysts’ waste auditors. We will help you with the Republic Services cancellation process, as well as auditing your invoices, ensuring the cost-effectiveness of your contracts, and catching overcharges.

The post How to Cancel Republic Services (Read This First) appeared first on P3 Cost Analysts.


The post Franchise Registration States: A Guide for Franchisees appeared first on P3 Cost Analysts.


To make things more clear, let’s explore the different types of franchise laws and highlight franchise registration states, franchise filing states, and franchise relationship states. Understanding these distinctions is crucial for both franchisors and prospective franchisees.


As with all things business-related, federal and state governments have implemented a set of laws to control how franchises are registered, sold, and contracted. These legal requirements are in place to regulate the relationship between franchisors (the companies granting franchises) and franchisees (the individuals or entities purchasing and operating a franchise).


The goal of these regulations is to provide a framework that promotes fairness, transparency, and protection for both parties. By establishing legal frameworks and guidelines, franchise laws provide a level of confidence and protection to prospective franchisees, encouraging entrepreneurship and promoting the growth of franchise businesses.


In the United States, federal franchise laws primarily revolve around the regulation of franchise sales and disclosures. The key federal franchise law is the Federal Trade Commission’s (FTC) Franchise Rule, which sets forth requirements for franchisors to provide prospective franchisees with certain information before they enter into a franchise agreement.


The Franchise Rule mandates that franchisors provide a Franchise Disclosure Document (FDD) to prospective franchisees at least 14 days before signing any agreement or making any payment. The FDD contains essential information about the franchisor, the franchise system, the franchise fee, ongoing costs, territory, trademarks, litigation history, and other relevant details.


While federal franchise laws primarily focus on disclosure requirements and preventing fraudulent or deceptive practices, other federal laws — such as employment, intellectual property, and antitrust laws — may also apply to franchising.


While federal franchise laws establish baseline requirements, state franchise laws often add additional provisions and requirements that franchisors and franchisees must adhere to. Franchisors must comply with the specific registration requirements in each state where they wish to offer franchises. Failure to do so can result in legal consequences, penalties, or even the inability to sell franchises in that state.


Each state has its own set of franchise registration laws, and the requirements can vary. Some states have rigorous registration processes, while others have more lenient procedures. Below, we take a look at the difference between franchise registration states, franchise filing states, and franchise relationship states.


Franchise registration states are U.S. states that require franchisors to register their franchise offering before selling franchises. These states have specific laws in place to protect prospective franchisees and ensure transparency. Franchisors must submit a comprehensive FDD that contains important information about the franchise opportunity. The FDD must be reviewed and approved by a state examiner who ensures that all state requirements have been filled.


For potential franchisees, registration states offer several benefits and implications. First, franchisees are guaranteed access to comprehensive information about potential franchise opportunities. This enables potential franchisees to make informed decisions and thoroughly evaluate various franchises.


The standardized and transparent disclosure process also ensures that franchisees have recourse and legal remedies if the franchisor fails to provide the required disclosures or engages in fraudulent or misleading practices.


Franchise filing states also require that franchises file specific documents and pay a fee. However, the difference is that there is no approval process. These requirements, while not as strict as franchise registration states, aim to provide transparency and protect the interests of prospective franchisees by ensuring that franchisors meet certain standards and obligations before operating within the state.


Franchise filing states offer some of the same benefits as registration states. However, since the filing requirements aren’t approved by the state, the level of protection isn’t the same. Still, franchise filing states offer increased transparency, regulatory oversight, state-specific protections, and enforcement mechanisms.


If a state does not have franchise registration or franchise filing requirements, it is generally referred to as a non-registration state or a non-filing state. In these states, franchisors are not required to submit specific documents or disclosures to state authorities before offering or selling franchises. However, even in non-registration states, franchisors are still obligated to comply with federal franchise laws and stay in accordance with the Federal Franchise Rule.


Despite the fact that these states still must follow federal regulations, there is limited state oversight in the franchising process. For franchisees, this enhances the importance of the due diligence process. Franchisees need to carefully review the FDD, seek legal advice, and conduct independent research to assess the viability and risks of the franchise opportunity. In addition, there may be fewer legal remedies in case of disputes with the franchisor or misrepresentation and unfair practices.


Join P3 Cost Analysts and become part of our cost reduction franchise team. With a low buy-in opportunity, franchisees gain access to hands-on training, support, and a suite of software tools to streamline their business operations. Our team of industry experts will guide you through the start-up training, teaching you the ins and outs of operational and consulting responsibilities, marketing strategies, and maintaining client relationships.


We currently have available territories in every state. Regardless of where you’re interested in opening your franchise, P3 will adhere to both federal and local state laws. Join us today and create a residual stream of income while helping businesses save on recurring costs.


Understanding franchise laws is crucial for both franchisors and prospective franchisees. Franchise registration states prioritize transparency and protection for franchisees by requiring franchisors to register their offerings and submit comprehensive disclosures. This ensures that potential franchisees have access to crucial information and legal remedies in case of fraudulent practices.


While franchise filing states also aim to provide transparency and protection, in non-registration states, franchisees must rely on federal regulations and exercise due diligence to assess the likelihood of success and potential risks of the franchise opportunity. Regardless of which state you’re in, the P3 Cost Analysts franchise opportunity offers a low buy-in investment, comprehensive training, ongoing support, and all necessary software to help franchisees succeed in the cost reduction industry.


Contact us today at 1-877-843-7579 or fill out the form on our franchising page, and we will answer any questions you have about the process and opportunity.


The post Franchise Registration States: A Guide for Franchisees appeared first on P3 Cost Analysts.


The post What Is UPS SurePost? (+ How to Save On UPS Shipping) appeared first on P3 Cost Analysts.


As businesses strive to meet the growing expectations of their customers, offering free shipping has emerged as a powerful strategy for boosting sales and enhancing customer satisfaction. However, for businesses to provide this enticing perk, they must navigate the complex realm of shipping logistics, where affordable shipping rates are key. UPS’s answer to this market need is its SurePost service.


Let’s take a closer look at the specifics of UPS SurePost, including how it works, how long it takes, the specific benefits, and other ways to save money on shipping costs.


UPS SurePost is a service offered by the United Parcel Service (UPS) that combines the efficiency of UPS’s ground network with the final delivery handled by the United States Postal Service (USPS). It is designed to provide an economical and convenient shipping option for lightweight, non-urgent packages. It is commonly used for e-commerce shipments, allowing businesses that ship at least ten packages daily to offer affordable shipping options to their customers.


The ideal SurePost package should be lightweight and compact enough to fit easily within a mail truck, weighing less than ten pounds and measuring under one cubic foot. Furthermore, the shipments should be destined for residential addresses, involve business-to-consumer transactions, possess a value below $100, and require only limited liability coverage. By meeting these requirements, shippers can leverage UPS SurePost to efficiently and affordably deliver their packages to customers.


As mentioned above, UPS SurePost operates through a strategic collaboration between UPS and the USPS. The process begins when businesses enter into a contractual agreement for UPS SurePost services, which often involves parcel contract negotiation. Initially, UPS handles the transportation of the packages from the sender’s location to a designated UPS facility. At this point, UPS consolidates and sorts the packages before transferring them to the USPS for the final mile delivery.


Once the packages are in the hands of the USPS, they are integrated into the existing USPS infrastructure for local delivery. USPS carriers transport the packages directly to their intended destinations, including residential addresses. Throughout the entire process, UPS provides robust tracking capabilities, allowing both businesses and customers to monitor the progress of their shipments and ensure transparency and peace of mind.


UPS SurePost packages are delivered by the United States Postal Service (USPS) as the last-mile carrier. The USPS is responsible for the final leg of the delivery process, bringing the packages directly to customers’ doorsteps. This delivery method is particularly well-suited for residential addresses and offers convenience for recipients who may not be available during regular business hours.


While the average UPS SurePost delivery time may vary based on factors such as distance, location, and local USPS operations, they typically align with the USPS’s regular delivery schedule. It’s important to note that delivery to certain areas, such as rural or remote regions, may have specific limitations or longer transit times due to USPS service coverage.


Additionally, UPS SurePost deliveries generally follow the USPS delivery calendar, which typically excludes Sunday deliveries. However, UPS SurePost packages can still be in transit during weekends as they move through the UPS and USPS networks. It’s advisable to check with UPS or USPS for any specific delivery exceptions or holiday schedules that may impact SurePost deliveries.


UPS SurePost and UPS Ground are two residential ground services offered by UPS that allow businesses to decide between focusing on lowering shipping costs or enhancing customer experience. Both services have their advantages, with UPS Ground offering comprehensive coverage and flexibility, while UPS SurePost is more economical and utilizes the USPS network for efficient last-mile delivery.


UPS Ground is delivered exclusively by UPS drivers, providing day-definite delivery typically within one to five business days. It offers multiple delivery attempts, a service guarantee, proof of delivery, and delivery of all package types. In addition, UPS Ground offers more value-added service options that aren’t available with SurePost, such as confirmation signatures, receiver management, and collect-on-delivery.


On the other hand, UPS SurePost is best suited for small and lightweight packages and leverages the single-carrier network of UPS. With SurePost, businesses can deliver to PO boxes and all US territories.


When it comes to shipping with UPS SurePost, there are several advantages that businesses can capitalize on. From robust tracking capabilities to expedited delivery times, UPS SurePost offers benefits that can enhance the shipping experience for both businesses and their customers.


UPS provides tracking capabilities for packages shipped with SurePost from start to finish. Businesses can monitor the progress of their shipments, ensuring transparency and peace of mind throughout the delivery process. Customers can also track their orders, offering them visibility and reassurance.


UPS doesn’t stage packages for consolidation before sending them out for final-mile delivery with USPS. This means packages move through the network quickly, speeding up delivery times.


One of the notable benefits of shipping with UPS SurePost is its commitment to environmental sustainability through carbon neutrality. UPS has taken significant steps to minimize its environmental impact and offers carbon-neutral shipping options for SurePost customers for $0.05 per package.


UPS SurePost is offered to businesses using a direct-to-consumer business model as well. This means that online retailers can also reap the benefits of this affordable shipping option, with UPS collecting parcels directly from their warehouse.


While UPS SurePost offers notable benefits, it’s important to consider potential limitations or drawbacks associated with this shipping service. By understanding these considerations, businesses can make informed decisions and determine if UPS SurePost aligns with their specific shipping requirements and objectives.


UPS can only offer SurePost deliveries to addresses that USPS delivers to. While their network does cover most addresses in the country, there are some rural areas that are not included. In addition, offshore and military destinations may be subject to longer delivery times.


For packages that cannot be delivered, if the shipper wants the package returned, they will incur postage fees from the USPS.


When shipping with UPS SurePost, businesses benefit from limited liability coverage of up to $100. This coverage provides a degree of financial protection in the event of loss, damage, or theft during transit. However, this liability is only up until the point of transfer to the USPS.


While choosing the right parcel delivery carrier and service offering is a huge step toward lowering shipping costs, there are other ways to save even more. If you’re looking to reduce shipping expenses and improve your bottom line, utilizing third-party companies like P3 Cost Analysts can make a significant difference. With our expertise in shipping contracts and invoicing audits, we can help save your business around 20 percent of your current delivery costs.


UPS SurePost is a contractual service, and carrier contracts can be complex and challenging to navigate, with different pricing tiers and fine print that can impact your costs. P3’s team of experts, comprised of former pricing analysts from major carriers, understands these intricacies and can provide insights to help you negotiate better deals.


In addition to securing better rates, third-party companies like P3 can also conduct thorough parcel invoice audits to ensure you’re not missing out on refunds and credits. Billions of dollars in shipping refunds go unclaimed each year, and our auditing process can help you identify and recover any owed refunds, providing a valuable boost to your bottom line.


What is the difference between UPS SurePost and UPS?


UPS is a shipping carrier that offers many different shipping services for companies and individuals alike. SurePost is one of their offerings that utilizes the USPS for the final mile delivery to residential addresses, resulting in cost savings for businesses.


Who is UPS SurePost delivered by?


The idea behind SurePost is that UPS handles the initial transportation of the packages, and then they are handed over to the USPS for local delivery. Initially, most UPS SurePost parcels were handled by the USPS for the final leg of the delivery. However, UPS now performs around 40 percent of packages’ final-mile delivery.


How does UPS SurePost tracking work?


Customers can track a SurePost package throughout the entire shipping process. UPS’s robust tracking capabilities follow parcels all the way through the final mile using the same tracking number.


Does UPS SurePost deliver on Sunday?


SurePost’s guaranteed delivery days are from Monday through Saturday. However, in some locations where USPS offers Sunday deliveries and UPS has Saturday operations, packages may be delivered on Sunday as well.


Is UPS SurePost safe?


Yes, UPS SurePost is generally considered safe for shipping packages. However, it’s important for businesses to ensure proper packaging to protect the contents during transportation. UPS provides guidelines and recommendations for packaging to ensure safe delivery. Still, with limited liability, high-value packages are best shipped through UPS Ground.


How reliable is UPS SurePost?


UPS SurePost is known to be a reliable shipping service, offering consistent delivery times and a track record of successful package transportation. However, delivery times may vary depending on factors such as origin and destination locations, weather conditions, and unforeseen circumstances.


Does UPS SurePost deliver to PO boxes?


Yes, UPS SurePost does deliver to PO boxes. The USPS is responsible for the final delivery of packages, and they have the capability to deliver to PO boxes as part of their standard mail services.


UPS SurePost is an excellent low-cost shipping option for businesses. It combines UPS’s ground network with USPS for final delivery, making it an affordable solution for lightweight packages. SurePost offers advantages like tracking, quick package movement, and carbon-neutral shipping. However, it’s important to consider delivery limitations and limited liability coverage.


If you’re ready to take control of your shipping costs and explore ways to save, consider partnering with a trusted third-party company like P3 Cost Analysts. We can help you negotiate the best conditions for your shipping contracts and audit ongoing invoices to ensure you’re not overpaying.


Schedule a consultation today to discover how we can help your business lower its shipping rates and improve its financial performance.


The post What Is UPS SurePost? (+ How to Save On UPS Shipping) appeared first on P3 Cost Analysts.


The post FedEx SmartPost: How It Worked and What Replaced It appeared first on P3 Cost Analysts.


One particular challenge in the shipping process is the last-mile delivery, which refers to the final leg of a package’s journey from a local distribution center to the customer’s address. Interestingly, this seemingly short distance can often be the most costly and complex part of package delivery.


FedEx is one shipping company that has recently changed how they handle land-mile package deliveries. In 2021, the company began the rebranding from FedEx SmartPost to FedEx Ground Economy to keep up with the explosive growth of e-commerce and optimize its last-mile delivery process. Today, we’ll look at the former FedEx SmartPost, the shift to FedEx Ground Economy, and what that means for businesses like yours.


FedEx SmartPost was a hybrid shipping service that combined the resources of FedEx and the U.S. Postal Service (USPS) for package delivery. It was designed to provide a cost-effective solution for shipping lightweight packages to residential addresses by combining the speed and reliability of FedEx’s express network with the extensive reach of the USPS for final delivery.


When still operating, FedEx SmartPost utilized FedEx’s extensive express network for long-distance transportation and then handed off the packages to USPS for last-mile delivery. This collaboration allowed FedEx SmartPost to reach every U.S. residential address, including PO boxes and military residences, while offering competitive shipping rates for businesses. Despite the last mile being operated by USPS, shippers still had tracking capabilities and service available Monday to Saturday.


The way FedEx SmartPost functioned allowed the shipping company to offer competitive shipping prices. However, the program was most useful for small, lightweight packages that weren’t time sensitive. Some shippers complained that the service was too slow or unreliable.


The transition from FedEx SmartPost to FedEx Ground Economy was driven by several factors and the need to adapt to a changing market. Here are some of the likely reasons behind this decision:


The rapid growth of e-commerce has led to a significant increase in package volume being shipped to residential addresses. This surge in online shopping has placed greater demands on shipping services to handle higher volumes efficiently. FedEx recognized the need to optimize its operations to meet the growing demand and provide an improved customer experience.


FedEx SmartPost’s hybrid model of utilizing both FedEx’s express network and the USPS for final delivery presented some operational complexities. The transition to FedEx Ground Economy aimed to streamline operations by consolidating operations within FedEx’s own network and utilizing contracted drivers. This allows FedEx to have more control over the entire shipping process, resulting in improved efficiency.


By focusing on ground transportation for the entire delivery process, FedEx can optimize routes, utilize its own delivery fleet more effectively, and potentially reduce costs associated with third-party partnerships.


Overall, the transition from FedEx SmartPost to Ground Economy was driven by the need to adapt to the changing landscape of e-commerce, optimize operational efficiency, reduce costs, and provide an improved shipping experience for customers. By streamlining operations and focusing on ground transportation, FedEx aimed to meet the evolving demands of the market while ensuring efficient and reliable package delivery.


While FedEx SmartPost relied on FedEx’s express network and USPS for last-mile delivery, FedEx Ground Economy operates solely within FedEx’s own network, providing more control over the entire delivery process. FedEx Ground drivers, or sometimes contracted third-party drivers, complete the last-mile delivery, bringing packages directly to recipients’ addresses.


These changes are an effort by FedEx to ensure greater reliability and faster transit times compared to SmartPost. One major change from SmartPost to Ground Economy is the addition of Sunday deliveries. Ground Economy is a strong contender for businesses looking for outbound deliveries that are low-weight and non-urgent. Still, the following options are not available for Ground Economy:


The shift from FedEx SmartPost to FedEx Ground Economy began in 2019 as the company began delivering most SmartPost packages through their networks. The official rebrand happened in 2021 when they publicly introduced FedEx Ground Economy. The slow transition and similar product offerings meant that the two programs have many similarities; however, there are some key differences as well.


SmartPost utilized a hybrid model, combining FedEx’s express network for long-distance transportation and the USPS for last-mile delivery. Packages were handed off from FedEx to the USPS for final delivery.


Ground Economy operates solely within FedEx’s own network. It relies on ground transportation methods, such as trucks, for the entire delivery process, without involving the USPS.


FedEx SmartPost shipping time was generally longer when compared to other FedEx services due to the involvement of the USPS for the last mile. Estimated FedEx SmartPost shipping time ranged from two to seven business days, depending on the distance and destination, and there were no Sunday deliveries.


Estimated delivery times for Ground Economy are similar to that of SmartPost. Deliveries range from two to seven business days, depending on the distance and destination. However, FedEx now delivers Monday through Sunday, allowing them to shorten the average delivery time.


SmartPost Returns followed a similar process to outbound delivery. To offer returns for their customers, businesses would include a prepaid shipping label along with the shipment. Then, the customer could leave the box in their mailbox, give it to their USPS carrier, or drop it off at a FedEx office.


Ground Economy returns functions nearly the same as FedEx SmartPost Returns. However, customers now have even more options, with the ability to print a shipping label from a QR code or create one online.


Tracking was available for packages delivered through SmartPost, even once the package was handed off to USPS. The 20-digital FedEx tracking number was converted to a USPS tracking number once the handoff was processed.


Now that Ground Economy handles delivery for the entire process, only the FedEx tracking number is needed.


Now that we understand the similarities and differences between FedEx Ground Economy and FedEx SmartPost, we can compare them with another popular delivery option, FedEx Home Delivery. First off, Home Delivery accepts packages up to 150 pounds, while Ground Economy has a maximum of 70 pounds. In addition, Home Delivery is a bit faster, with deliveries made between one and five business days.


However, perhaps one of the largest differences between the two programs is the contractual agreement. Ground Economy is a contract service, meaning businesses must sign an agreement with FedEx outlining the terms and conditions of the contract. Meanwhile, Home Delivery is not a contract service.


The rebranding of FedEx SmartPost to FedEx Ground Economy brings significant implications for shippers. Parcel management, with its inherent complexities and risks, requires careful attention to avoid unnecessary costs. By eliminating the handoff to USPS and taking responsibility for final mile delivery in-house, FedEx aims to streamline the process and enhance efficiency.


However, this shift still necessitates FedEx contract negotiation and thorough FedEx invoice auditing to ensure accurate rates and maximize return on investment. Companies must be vigilant in monitoring any invoice errors or unjust surcharges on their bills each month.


The importance of analytics and shipment auditing cannot be overstated in today’s shipping industry. To address these challenges and optimize small parcel shipping costs, partnering with a cost reduction firm is your best choice. Companies like P3 Cost Analysts can provide invaluable expertise and solutions. By leveraging comprehensive analytics and auditing capabilities, we help shippers make informed decisions, uncover savings opportunities, and enhance their overall shipping strategies.


The exponential growth of e-commerce and the need for operational efficiency and cost optimization have prompted FedEx to streamline its operations and bring the entire delivery process in-house. By eliminating the transfer to USPS and relying solely on its own network, FedEx aims to enhance reliability, shorten transit times, and provide a better shipping experience for customers.


While the transition from SmartPost to Ground Economy offers several benefits, one thing remains constant regardless of which parcel delivery service business owners choose. Shippers must carefully review their contracts with FedEx, negotiate favorable terms, and conduct thorough invoice auditing to ensure accurate rates and avoid unnecessary costs.


Partnering with a cost reduction firm like P3 Cost Analysts can provide valuable expertise and solutions in navigating the complexities of small parcel shipping. We will help you get control over your shipping expenses and make sure the delivery companies are working for you.


For help in all aspects of parcel delivery, contact a P3 shipping expert today!


The post FedEx SmartPost: How It Worked and What Replaced It appeared first on P3 Cost Analysts.


In the world of business, cost management is a perpetual challenge. Companies across various industries are contending with increasing MRO (Maintenance, Repair, and Operations) expenses, which can significantly impact their financial well-being.


If not carefully managed, MRO spending can become a financial burden for organizations of all types and sizes. However, where there are expenses, there’s also an opportunity for cost-saving measures to improve the bottom line. In this blog, we’ll look into the world of MRO procurement, uncovering the vital role it plays in businesses and how effectively managing it can be the key to financial stability and growth.


MRO purchasing, also known as MRO procurement, is the process of acquiring goods and services necessary for the day-to-day operations and maintenance of a business. MRO, which stands for Maintenance, Repair, and Operations, is a vital component of indirect procurement, which deals with non-production-related expenses. These purchases cover a broad spectrum of items essential to keep a company’s operations running smoothly.


In certain industries, such as healthcare, there’s a greater emphasis on indirect procurement, including MRO purchasing, versus direct procurement. This emphasis stems from the fact that these service-based industries heavily rely on the continuous functionality of equipment and facilities. In contrast, manufacturing industries may place more emphasis on direct procurement, focusing on sourcing materials directly related to their production processes.


MRO purchasing encompasses a wide variety of procurement needs that are essential to the smooth and uninterrupted operation of a company. These MRO purchases can be conveniently categorized into three primary groups, each serving a distinct role in ensuring the seamless operation of a company:


This category of MRO purchases primarily focuses on items necessary for the routine upkeep and maintenance of machinery, equipment, and facilities. It includes a range of components and supplies, such as:


The repairs category of MRO purchases encompasses items and resources required for addressing unexpected breakdowns or malfunctions in machinery and equipment. It includes:


The final category of MRO purchases — operations — covers services and supplies essential for the daily functioning of a business. This category includes items such as:


Companies often face a series of challenges in the MRO procurement process, each with the potential to impact their bottom line and overall operational efficiency significantly.


In many organizations, MRO procurement tends to be decentralized, with different departments or locations independently managing their needs. This separation can lead to inefficiencies as it often results in duplicate orders, missed opportunities for bulk purchasing discounts, and a lack of visibility into overall spending. Consequently, businesses may experience increased costs that could have been avoided with a more centralized and streamlined procurement approach.


The complexity of managing a wide range of MRO suppliers is a common issue. Sourcing various parts, equipment, and services from multiple suppliers can become time-consuming and overwhelming. Furthermore, dealing with numerous suppliers can lead to inconsistent service levels, making it challenging to maintain reliable and efficient supply chains.


Effective inventory control in MRO procurement is an ongoing struggle for many companies. Finding the right balance between maintaining adequate stock levels to ensure operational continuity and minimizing carrying costs is a constant challenge. Overstocked inventories tie up capital and storage space, while understocked inventories can lead to costly production disruptions. Striking this balance requires careful planning, forecasting, and demand management.


Some MRO components are highly specialized and only needed at specific times. Managing the procurement of such specialized items can be challenging, as it requires predicting when and where these components will be required. Failing to anticipate these needs accurately can result in delays, increased downtime, and higher costs.


To effectively manage MRO spend, businesses employ a range of strategic approaches tailored to their unique needs and challenges:


The implementation of advanced procurement software and tools is essential in MRO strategy. These technological solutions offer enhanced visibility into procurement processes, allowing businesses to track orders, monitor inventory levels, and identify cost-saving opportunities. By leveraging technology, companies gain greater control over their MRO spend, reduce manual administrative tasks, and enhance overall efficiency.


Many companies find value in streamlining their supplier base when it comes to MRO procurement. By reducing the number of MRO suppliers, organizations simplify supplier management, negotiation processes, and administrative tasks. This consolidation not only enhances efficiency but can also lead to better pricing agreements through increased purchasing volume.


Leveraging data analytics has become a critical aspect of modern MRO strategy. By harnessing the power of data, businesses can make informed procurement decisions, optimize inventory levels, and anticipate future needs more accurately. Data-driven insights enable proactive maintenance planning, reducing downtime and mitigating the risk of emergency procurements that can be costly. Additionally, data analytics help identify trends, anomalies, and areas for cost savings within the MRO procurement process.


One of the most effective approaches to MRO strategy is centralizing procurement. By consolidating the responsibility for MRO purchasing, companies can achieve greater consistency, better coordination, and improved cost control. Centralization fosters better alignment between departments, ensuring that MRO purchases meet the specific needs of each function. This collaborative approach enhances communication, streamlines decision-making, and ultimately results in more effective and cost-conscious procurement practices.


These strategies collectively empower businesses to take a proactive approach to managing their MRO spend, enhancing efficiency, reducing costs, and ensuring the seamless operation of their facilities and equipment.


Implementing the comprehensive strategies we’ve explored for managing MRO purchasing effectively can be a complex task, especially when juggling various priorities within your organization. This is where partnering with a specialized cost reduction consulting firm like P3 Cost Analysts becomes your strategic advantage.


At P3, we specialize in optimizing procurement practices across a wide spectrum of non-production-related expenses. Our expert team brings decades of experience and industry knowledge to the table, making it easier for your business to implement these strategies quickly and cost-effectively.


We understand that MRO procurement is a multifaceted challenge, and that’s why we offer a range of services tailored to your specific needs. By exploring our services, you’ll find valuable solutions that seamlessly align with the strategies we’ve discussed. Whether it’s centralizing procurement, consolidating suppliers, or harnessing the power of data analytics, P3 has you covered.


Take the next step toward a more efficient and cost-conscious MRO procurement process for your business. Explore our services, schedule a free call, and speak with one of our cost reduction experts today.

Last mile delivery, the crucial link between businesses and customers, plays a vital role in customer satisfaction and the success of e-commerce and retail operations. The last mile delivery industry is evolving rapidly as the demand for faster, cheaper, and more convenient delivery options grows.


This article will explore the top last mile delivery companies and startups this year, shedding light on established industry leaders and emerging disruptors. Whether you’re looking for reliable global logistics giants or innovative local players, this comprehensive guide will help you navigate the ever-changing landscape of last mile logistics.


Last mile delivery is the final stage and arguably the most important part of the logistics process. This leg of the delivery process refers to when goods are transported from a distribution or fulfillment center to the customer’s doorstep. It is the crucial link between businesses and consumers. Last mile delivery plays a significant role in customer satisfaction and the overall success of e-commerce and retail operations.


The process from customer purchase to last mile delivery looks something like this. First, a customer places an order, usually through an online retailer. The company then processes, packs, and prepares the item for shipment from its fulfillment center. At this point, the delivery vehicle will collect the product. Last mile delivery may be handled by the company themselves, such as with Amazon, or via a third party. Either way, the shipper is responsible for optimizing delivery routes for efficiency. Once the package has been delivered, the driver marks the order as complete.


In recent years, the growth of e-commerce has led to an increased emphasis on last mile delivery services. Customers now expect faster, more convenient, and more flexible delivery options. E-commerce giants like Amazon have placed pressure on smaller companies to keep up with these advancements.


While Amazon handles its own shipping needs, other businesses often rely on third-party last mile delivery companies to ship their products. These providers have responded to growing industry pressure by adopting innovative technologies – such as route optimization software, tracking systems, and delivery drones or robots – to streamline their last mile operations. In addition to the major players, we are now seeing startup companies looking to disrupt the industry, as well as software to help businesses optimize their shipping processes.


Industry trends in last mile logistics mirror those of many other industries. As technology advances, people prioritize sustainability, and the demands of consumers evolve, each sector must adapt.


Each year, the technological advancements in the industry continue to surprise us. One trend that is taking the industry by storm is robotics and automation. Self-driving delivery vehicles, drones, and other autonomous vehicles can not only lower costs and improve delivery times but also improve traffic issues. Additional technological advancements include AI route optimization, real-time communication tools, and GPS tracking systems.


Sustainability has become a key focus in the last mile delivery sector. With increasing environmental concerns and pressure from the masses, companies are adopting more sustainable practices to reduce carbon emissions. This includes the use of electric vehicles and alternative fuel sources, as well as optimizing delivery routes to minimize fuel consumption. Some companies are also exploring more localized fulfillment operations, utilizing eco-friendly packaging materials, and implementing recycling programs to reduce waste.


Enhancing the customer experience is a top priority for last mile delivery providers. Real-time tracking systems allow customers to monitor the progress of their deliveries and receive accurate estimated arrival times. Delivery notifications through SMS or mobile apps enable customers to plan their schedules accordingly. Moreover, personalized delivery options, such as choosing delivery time windows or designated safe drop-off locations, contribute to a more convenient and satisfying customer experience.


The demand for faster deliveries, including same-day and on-demand services, has grown significantly. Last mile delivery providers are adapting to this trend by offering expedited delivery options. Some companies have developed networks of local couriers or crowd-sourced drivers to fulfill immediate delivery requests. Additionally, partnerships with brick-and-mortar stores or lockers enable customers to pick up or return orders at convenient locations.


These well-established industry leaders have built a strong reputation and extensive networks in the last mile delivery space. With their focus on optimization, reliability, and innovative solutions, they have set the benchmark for efficient and effective delivery services.


UPS, a renowned global logistics company that rakes in nearly 100 billion in annual revenue, specializes in last mile delivery services. It places significant emphasis on optimizing its last mile capabilities through strategic partnerships and technology integration. UPS’s commitment to efficient and reliable last mile delivery has contributed to its strong presence in the industry.


FedEx distinguishes itself from other last mile delivery services through its extensive global network and comprehensive range of services. With a strong focus on reliability and speed, FedEx offers express delivery solutions that enable businesses to meet tight deadlines. Their advanced tracking capabilities, innovative technology, and commitment to exceptional customer service make FedEx a top choice for domestic and international shipping needs.


USPS, while not quite as fast as some of its competitors, stands out from other shippers with its extensive nationwide coverage and affordable shipping options. As a government agency, USPS provides universal service, reaching every address in the country. Its reliable delivery network, including Saturday and Sunday deliveries, competitive pricing, and various services, make it a preferred choice for individuals and businesses shipping smaller, lightweight packages.


DHL is another massive, worldwide shipping company that offers some of the best options for international shipping. DHL provides comprehensive resources aimed at assisting business owners in navigating complex shipping procedures when sending goods across borders. This includes valuable guidance on topics such as import and export taxes, enabling businesses to have a better understanding of the intricacies involved in cross-border shipping.


Amazon, known for its disruptive impact on the retail industry and the rise of the digital marketplace, has significantly influenced the last mile distribution industry. Referred to as “the Amazon Effect,” it has reshaped customer expectations and accelerated delivery times. Each year, Amazon continues enhancing its delivery options, striving for ever-increasing speed and efficiency. Its expansive logistics network and focus on fast, reliable shipping have made Amazon a driving force in the industry.


OnTrac has been aiming to disrupt the big national shipping carriers, claiming they deliver on average one to two days faster than their large competitors. They currently offer last mile delivery services that reach over 80 percent of the population, and they are continuing to expand. They focus on finding creative shipping solutions for sellers to pinpoint more cost-effective delivery options.


These up-and-coming players are disrupting the last mile delivery landscape with their fresh approaches and innovative solutions. Leveraging technology and unique business models, they offer new options and experiences for businesses and consumers alike, setting the stage for the future of last mile logistics.


Postmates varies from the others on our list in that it is a personal on-demand delivery platform that connects customers with local couriers to fulfill their delivery needs. With a user-friendly app and website, Postmates offers a wide range of delivery options, including food, groceries, and other goods. Their quick and convenient service that mirrors food delivery apps, real-time tracking, and flexible delivery options make Postmates a popular choice for fast and efficient last mile delivery of local products.


Hitch is an emerging last mile delivery startup that focuses on creating a peer-to-peer delivery network. Through their platform, individuals can sign up to become drivers and fulfill delivery requests from local businesses and individuals. Hitch leverages existing transportation routes and connects senders with available drivers, offering a cost-effective and efficient solution for intercity deliveries in Texas, Oklahoma, and Florida. With a community-driven approach, Hitch aims to revolutionize the way goods are delivered by leveraging the power of individuals in the gig economy.


Dropoff is an on-demand, same-day custom courier service designed for businesses. With a focus on reliability, professionalism, and convenience, Dropoff offers businesses the ability to schedule and track same-day deliveries in real-time. Their network of professional drivers ensures prompt and secure delivery of goods, making Dropoff a trusted partner for businesses seeking efficient and high-quality last-mile delivery solutions.


Nuro is a leading autonomous delivery company specializing in developing and deploying self-driving vehicles for last-mile delivery. With their advanced robotics and AI technology, Nuro is revolutionizing how goods are transported, providing a safe and efficient solution for last mile logistics. Their compact, purpose-built vehicles navigate seamlessly to deliver packages, groceries, and other goods, offering a glimpse into the future of autonomous last-mile delivery.


Matternet is an innovative company that focuses on developing autonomous drone delivery systems for last mile logistics. Their advanced technology enables safe, efficient, and reliable transportation of goods through the air. Matternet’s drones are designed to navigate complex urban environments, providing swift and eco-friendly delivery solutions for critical medical supplies, e-commerce, and other time-sensitive deliveries. With its cutting-edge approach, Matternet is reshaping the future of last mile logistics through drone delivery capabilities.


Instacart is a popular on-demand grocery delivery platform connecting customers with personal shoppers to fulfill grocery orders. With a user-friendly app or website, Instacart offers a convenient shopping experience, allowing customers to order groceries from their favorite local stores. Dedicated shoppers handpick the items and deliver them directly to customers’ doorsteps. Instacart’s reliable service, wide store selection, and flexible delivery options make it a go-to choice for convenient grocery shopping and last mile delivery.


In addition to the traditional final mile delivery companies and newer startups, there are other ventures that focus on logistics and optimization. These businesses aim to improve last mile distribution through software platforms that optimize the process. Here are some last mile logistics and SaaS companies shaking up the industry.


Onfleet is a leading delivery management software platform that enables businesses to optimize their last mile operations. With its intuitive software and robust features, Onfleet streamlines dispatching, real-time driver tracking, and customer and driver communication. Its scalable and flexible solution empowers businesses to manage and track their deliveries efficiently, enhancing customer satisfaction and operational efficiency.


Fareye is a logistics technology company offering a comprehensive end-to-end logistics management platform. It specializes in providing all-in-one low-code/no-code logistics solutions to streamline operations, optimize routes, track shipments, and enhance overall efficiency. Fareye’s software prioritizes agility and adaptability, simplifying the delivery journey and creating new delivery models.


ClickPost is a technology platform that offers a comprehensive and streamlined solution for e-commerce shipping and logistics. With Clickpost, businesses can easily switch between shipping carriers using an AI-powered engine. The platform integrates with over 350 shipping partners and provides end-to-end visibility, making it easier for companies to optimize their e-commerce logistics operations and deliver a seamless customer experience.


The last mile delivery landscape is experiencing disruptions from startups and software companies introducing innovative solutions. However, these newcomers may not be equipped to handle the scale of large e-commerce businesses just yet. In such cases, it is essential to rely on one of the major players in the industry. Unfortunately for business owners, while these big last mile delivery companies usually offer great services, they often come with billing errors, overcharges, and mistakes on their invoices. These issues can cost businesses a fortune.


Utilizing a third-party auditing service like P3 Cost Analysts becomes crucial to ensure cost-effectiveness and avoid overcharging or incorrect fees. By examining invoices and verifying charges, businesses can ensure they are benefiting from the most cost-effective solutions and optimizing their last mile delivery operations. However, this process is time-consuming and complicated, so working with a cost reduction firm like P3 is the most affordable way for businesses to lower their last mile delivery costs.


With a multitude of final mile delivery companies to choose from, the decision-making process can be overwhelming for business owners. In such cases, seeking help from last mile shipping professionals can be the easiest and most effective solution.


P3 Cost Analysts can assist by evaluating your current shipping providers, identifying steps to lower costs, and providing ongoing monitoring of invoices. Don’t let the complexities of last mile delivery burden you – reach out to P3 Cost Analysts today for expert guidance and start optimizing your shipping operations for maximum expense savings.

As a successful franchisee, Chris Atkinson maintains the importance of building mutually beneficial relationships with clients and stakeholders. Recessions are a natural part of the economic cycle, coming and going like the tides. Despite the inevitable economic challenges, entrepreneurs pour their time, energy, and resources into starting their companies, hoping for success even during times of economic uncertainty.


Savvy entrepreneurs understand that waiting for the “perfect” moment to start a business is futile. A better tactic is to opt for a company that can withstand the test of time and economic downturns by choosing recession-proof industries.


In this blog, we’ll explore ten recession-proof business ideas that can offer the potential for lasting success and stability, regardless of the economic climate. Let’s dive into these opportunities and discover how specific businesses that do well in a recession can provide peace of mind for entrepreneurs in both prosperous and challenging times.


A recession-proof business is one that is not as heavily impacted by the economic effects of a recession, typically stemming from industries that provide basic needs. Because they offer needed products and services, they are the last industries to be affected by changes in consumer spending.


To be clear, there is no such thing as a fully recession-proof business. Every recession is completely different and impossible to predict. For example, the real estate market crashed in 2008 but actually thrived during the early 2000s recession. However, some recession-proof industries are much more likely to weather the storm, regardless of what causes the economy to falter.


Recession-proof businesses are those found in sectors that thrive even during economic downturns, such as:


Recession-proof businesses typically cater to non-negotiable needs, offering products or services that people cannot easily forgo. By providing essential solutions, these businesses ensure their relevance and demand even during economic downturns.


Additionally, sustaining affordable prices plays a crucial role in their resilience during challenging times. When consumers become more budget-conscious in recessions, businesses offering competitive pricing are generally better positioned to retain customers and maintain a steady revenue stream.


Regardless of how the economy looks when you decide to start your own business, setting yourself up with a recession-proof business is a solid plan. You never know what the future holds, and these business ideas can give you some assurance now and for years to come.


The automotive services industry includes all post-purchase services necessary to keep a car in working order, such as oil changes, tire repairs, air conditioning, electrical inspections, plus body repair, painting, and much more.


The market is expected to register a 3 percent compound annual growth rate over the next five years and reach a value of $76.91 billion by 2027.


If people aren’t out buying new cars, you can best believe they’re doing everything they can to take care of the ones they have. Cars inevitably need maintenance as they age and have more miles put on them, even during a recession. Plus, as long as the freight industry continues to remain strong, there will be a need for servicing big rigs and delivery trucks.


Times have changed, and more and more families have two working parents, whether out of necessity or personal preference. Paid childcare services provide supervision, care, and sometimes education to infants and young children.


Childcare services were valued at $54.3 billion in 2019 and will continue to grow. From 2020 to 2027, there is an expected compound annual growth rate of 3.9 percent.


During a recession, parents may have to work longer hours or even more than one job. While historically expensive, childcare services are still one of the last costs parents abandon. Not to mention they usually make up a significant part of their budget. It’s not just about a safe place to leave your child while you’re at work. For many, it’s the first step of their growth and education.


The real estate industry involves the sale of land, residential, commercial, and industrial properties. But, there are other businesses involving real estate that may also thrive during a recession, like property management or investment firms.


Zillow Group expects that home value will continue to rise, going up 7.8 percent in the next 12 months.


It might surprise you to see real estate on our list when you consider the Great Recession. However, historically speaking, a recession does not always mean the housing market will crash. As of right now, home prices continue to soar, but even if prices drop, it may be the perfect opportunity for investors.


While prices fluctuate short term, the sector is usually more stable in the long run. Real estate even proved to be one of the most pandemic-proof businesses as the housing market boomed.


Millions of businesses and firms seek outside help regarding accounting and other financial information services, as do individuals. With rules and regulations getting more complicated and confusing, consulting experts seems to be the go-to move. Services offered include tax preparation, bookkeeping, and invoice outsourcing.


Worldwide, the financial services market grew from $2.5 trillion to $3.3 trillion between 2010 and 2018.


Even if the economy slows down, it never comes to a full halt. In fact, financial services drive the economy. So, many financial and accounting services continue to do well during hard times.


Home improvement services encompass a wide range of offerings aimed at enhancing and maintaining residential properties. These services can include renovations, remodeling, repairs, and upgrades to various areas of a home, such as kitchens, bathrooms, flooring, roofing, and more. Whether homeowners want to increase their property’s value, create a more comfortable living space, or address necessary repairs, the home improvement industry caters to their diverse needs.


The home improvement industry accounted for $538 billion in 2021 and is expected to reach more than $620 billion by 2025.


Certain services this industry provides, such as HVAC repair, electric, and home repair, are necessary even during a recession. AC units don’t care about the economic situation, but many Americans live in areas where you simply cannot live without it. Damaged roofs, leaking pipes, and other issues will still need to be repaired immediately. Home improvement also turned out to be a covid-proof business. With people stuck at home, many decided to fix up their houses.


Americans sure do love their pets. The animal care industry is massive and covers many different categories, including medical care, toys, daycare, and more. As people become more educated on animals’ needs and welfare, they are highly aware of where they put their money when it comes to their pets.


The global pet care market is expected to grow to more than 325 billion by 2028, with dog products and services pulling in the highest revenues.


If you believe everything you read on the internet, millennials have canceled having children and are having pets instead. Especially after the pandemic, the pet industry is breaking records, and proper pet care is not something most people are willing to forgo when money gets tight.


Business consulting includes a broad range of professional services other companies need help with, such as strategy, market research, or public relations. Consultants or consulting firms are meant to help their clients by solving specific problems or issues, often saving them money.


From freelancers to large firms, consulting businesses are generating up to $300 billion in annual revenues.


Consulting businesses can stay afloat during recessions because of their ability to be flexible and adapt to market situations. If companies are struggling to make money and you can help them create growth or optimize during a recession, they will want to keep you around. Plus, staying profitable will be much easier with no inventory and little overhead.


The SaaS market has grown at insane speeds over the past ten years and isn’t likely to slow down. Software as a service is delivered via the internet rather than installing complicated software and hardware. As a cloud-based service, the ease, scalability, and security are high, and users typically pay a monthly or yearly fee.


The rapid growth is expected to continue, with the market estimated to be worth about $208 billion in 2023, with US companies leading the way.


The SaaS industry is another with little to no overhead, making them easier for businesses to maintain during a recession. In addition, many of these software are fully integrated into business processes, so companies can’t afford to ditch them during a recession.


The healthcare industry includes a wide range of services, from hospitals and medical clinics to pharmaceutical companies and medical equipment manufacturers. The healthcare sector is dedicated to promoting, maintaining, and restoring human health through medical and therapeutic interventions.


According to Statista, the healthcare market is expected to reach nearly $59 billion in 2023 and show an annual growth rate of 10.4 percent in the years to come.


Healthcare is a fundamental need that people cannot do without, regardless of the economic situation. During a recession, individuals may cut back on unnecessary spending, but they will continue to seek medical care when necessary. Moreover, the recent global pandemic has highlighted the significance of pandemic-proof businesses in the healthcare industry. The ability to provide essential medical services, telehealth consultations, and innovative solutions while adapting to rapidly changing circumstances has highlighted the industry’s resilience.


According to Statista, in 2020, about 16.9 percent of the United States population was 65 or older. By 2030, that percentage is projected to reach 20.6 percent. This demographic shift emphasizes the demand for senior services for this growing population segment.


Senior services may include a range of businesses that cater to the needs of the elderly population. As people age, they may require assistance with daily activities, healthcare, companionship, and other specialized services to maintain a high quality of life.


The aging population’s continuous growth has led to an increased need for senior services, making this one of the most recession-proof industries. For many elderly individuals, these services are crucial for their well-being and safety, ensuring their relevance even during economic downturns. Additionally, the expansion of retirement communities and assisted living facilities opens up further opportunities for entrepreneurs in this field.


Starting an entire business from scratch can be costly, take a while to get things moving, and have no guarantee of success after all your hard work and dedication. A recession-proof franchise can take a lot of the guesswork out of the equation and help you get your business up and running much faster.


Franchising offers a proven business model with established brand recognition, training, and ongoing support from the franchisor. By investing in a recession-proof franchise, such as one with P3 Cost Analysts, you can leverage the expertise and experience of a well-established brand, increasing your chances of success even during challenging economic times. Additionally, as part of a larger network, you can benefit from collective buying power, marketing resources, and shared knowledge.


In uncertain economic times, having a recession-proof business can provide stability and security. The listed recession-proof business ideas cover various industries, from automotive services and child care to real estate and healthcare. By identifying essential products that people will continue to seek even during a recession, you can position your business for long-term success.


If you’re looking for an opportunity for business ownership in a sector that will thrive during all economic conditions, a cost reduction consulting franchise with P3 Cost Analysts could be the right move. If you have a passion for helping other business owners and want to help them cut costs during a recession, then you would shine with a cost reduction consulting franchise.


If you’re interested in learning more about starting a cost reduction consulting franchise, call us at 1-877-843-7579 or email us to speak with a franchise expert.
